Early and intense wildfire season has arrived around the Mediterranean
description: As of July 8, some 214,000 hectares have been ravaged by flames in the European Union, more than double the average. Fires have broken out further north in Europe, and the eastern Mediterranean region has also been struck.

The young Gazans killed at Al-Baqa café
description: On June 30, an Israeli airstrike killed dozens in a Gaza City café. Many young professionals, who embody Gazan resilience after 21 devastating months of war, died that day. Here are the stories of four of them.

headline: French army withdraws last troops from Senegal bases
description: The 350 remaining French soldiers in Senegal handed back the Camp Geille base in a ceremony on Thursday, July 17.

headline: Tour de France: Pogacar reclaims yellow jersey with dominant solo win
description: Tadej Pogacar stormed to victory on stage 12 of the Tour de France Thursday, dropping his rivals on the Hautacam climb to retake the overall lead.

headline: In 1945, 'Elle' instantly set a new standard for French women's magazines
description: 'The Summer of 1945' (4/6). Hélène Gordon-Lazareff, who spent much of World War Two in the United States, returned to France with fresh ideas for the press. She promised her readers 'seriousness in frivolity, irony in gravity.'

Gaza: Video verified by Le Monde shows gunfire near food distribution center
description: The video was filmed in Rafah, nearly 900 meters from a Gaza Humanitarian Foundation aid distribution center. According to the United Nations, over 800 people have been killed in Gaza since the end of May while trying to access humanitarian aid.

headline: Our eight favorite photo exhibitions to see in Arles this summer
description: Among the many offerings at the Rencontres d'Arles photography festival, we have selected a diverse range of exhibitions to see through October.

headline: 'His return was a miracle, but he had changed': The first free summer of Lyon's Holocaust survivors
description: 'The Summer of 1945' (3/6). As Lyon celebrated the Liberation, survivors of the death camps tried to reconnect with daily life, despite hardship, silence, and widespread incomprehension.
